overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, practitioner-driven guide to how venture capital financings actually work, written to demystify the language, mechanics, and human dynamics behind term sheets and venture transactions. The book opens by mapping the players you will meet in a fundraising process — entrepreneurs, VCs, angels, syndicates, lawyers, and advisors — and explains their motivations and incentives, setting the stage for why particular economic and control provisions appear in term sheets. From that foundation the authors step through the anatomy of a term sheet: the economic levers (valuation, liquidation preferences, option pools, antidilution) and the control levers (board composition, protective provisions, conversion mechanics), explaining not just definitions but the strategic consequences of each clause.

The book continually shifts to an entrepreneur’s perspective: practical negotiation tactics, how to manage exclusivity (no-shop) periods, how to handle information rights, registration and transfer restrictions, proprietary-information and invention assignments, and the trade-offs involved in founder activity and vesting clauses. It also teaches the essential arithmetic of cap tables, showing how post-money option pools, founder dilution, and share pricing interact in ways that often surprise first-time founders. Convertible debt and alternative seed instruments (notes, SAFEs/KISS) get a careful treatment too, with clear examples of discounts, caps, maturities, and conversion triggers and the risks each structure can pose.

Legal fundamentals that routinely trip up startups — employment law practices, entity choice (why VCs usually require C corporations), and tax-critical decisions like the 83(b) election — are called out as must-know items rather than optional lawyer-only details. The book closes by expanding the scope beyond single financings to community-level dynamics (the Boulder Thesis) that explain where and how startup ecosystems thrive, emphasizing long-term leadership, inclusivity, and active programming. Throughout, the authors emphasize transparency, precise math, and preparing founders to be equal partners in negotiations rather than passive recipients of VC terms.
key_themes: Demystifying venture capital language and process
Two negotiation axes: economics versus control
Practical negotiation strategy from the entrepreneur’s perspective
Precision in cap-table math and the real impact of dilution
Legal preparedness and routine legal pitfalls
Seed-stage financing alternatives and conversion mechanics
Ecosystem building and long-term community commitment
learning_objectives: Understand who the players are in a venture financing and what each party wants
Read, interpret, and negotiate the core economic and control provisions of a term sheet
Model pre- and post-money cap tables, including option-pool impact and share pricing
Evaluate when to use convertible notes or SAFEs and how caps, discounts, and maturities affect outcomes
Recognize key legal issues (entity choice, employment, 83(b) elections) that materially affect company value
Apply entrepreneur-focused tactics (handling no-shop clauses, information rights, ROFR/co-sale) to preserve leverage
Think beyond individual deals to how communities and long-term commitments shape startup success

Chapter 1, “The Players,” lays out the human landscape behind venture deals by defining each party you will meet in a fundraising process and describing their motivations, incentives, and typical behaviors. Building on the Introduction’s framing of why term sheets matter, the chapter profiles the entrepreneur and the venture capitalist (including how VCs evaluate opportunities), explains financing round nomenclature (seed, Series A, B, etc.), and distinguishes types of investors — from angel investors and syndicates to corporate and strategic investors. It also covers supporting roles that materially affect deal outcomes: the lead investor, lawyers, and mentors/advisors, emphasizing how each influences negotiation, diligence, and post-investment governance.

The chapter’s practical orientation prepares the reader for the detailed mechanics that follow in later chapters. Understanding who negotiates which terms and why clarifies why certain economic (price, liquidation preference, antidilution) and control (board seats, protective provisions, drag-along) provisions emerge the way they do. By the end of the chapter the reader should be able to map typical deal dynamics — who drives valuation, who insists on protective provisions, how syndicates are assembled, and why founders need experienced legal counsel and aligned mentors — setting the stage for the term-sheet deep dives in subsequent chapters.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

<!-- PageNumber="xiii" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="xiv Foreword" -->

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

The Foreword and Preface set the tone and purpose of the book: to demystify the opaque language and structures of venture capital term sheets for entrepreneurs and new entrants. The Foreword (anecdote from Fred Wilson) illustrates how basic but critical terms like “pre-money” can be a barrier to participation and how increased transparency—through blogs and guides—helps level the playing field. The Preface explains the book’s origin in the Term Sheet Series, the authors’ experience in hundreds of financings, and their aim to create a practical, balanced guide that covers not only term-sheet language but also the players, process, negotiation tactics, and why documents exist as they do.

The Preface also provides a roadmap for the book’s structure and shows how the material will build on what Chapter 1 introduced about “The Players.” Readers are told to expect chapters on the history of term sheets, how to prepare to raise capital, and deep dives into specific term-sheet categories (economics, control, and other terms). The Preface promises chapters on convertible debt versus equity, a new section on crowdfunding, how venture firms operate (incentives and compensation), negotiation strategy, acquisition letters of intent, and practical legal tips—plus entrepreneurial commentary by Matt Blumberg to provide the founder’s viewpoint. Overall, this chapter frames the book as a hands-on, staged learning path from human dynamics to technical terms to strategy and execution.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals: Be Smarter than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist, Third Edition By Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson Copyright @ 2016 by Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson" -->
chapter_summaries.summary: This chapter, “Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet,” grounds the reader in why term sheets matter by tracing their evolution (from the DEC/AR&D one‑page deal to today’s roughly eight‑page industry standard) and by emphasizing the two negotiation axes that actually matter: economics and control. It frames the term sheet as the point where many disparate humans, incentives, and legal mechanisms meet, and explains that although definitive legal documents have become more standardized, the term sheet negotiation is where the hard, value‑defining work happens. The chapter then turns practical: it profiles the players you will meet (VCs at every level of the firm, angels, syndicate leads, lawyers, operating partners, mentors), explains financing nomenclature (Seed, Series A/B/C, pre‑seed and numerical extensions like B‑1), and outlines the roles, incentives, and typical behaviors of each participant.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 5 takes the high-level framing from Chapter 4—the two negotiation axes of economics and control—and turns it into a practical walkthrough of the specific provisions that determine each axis. Building on the Foreword's and Preface's emphasis on demystifying term‑sheet language, this chapter catalogs economic terms (price/valuation, option pool, warrants, liquidation preference, pay‑to‑play, vesting and exercise periods, dividends, redemption, and antidilution) and control terms (board composition, protective provisions, conversion mechanics and automatic conversion thresholds). Each concept is explained in plain terms, with entrepreneur‑focused advice on what to prioritize, what to avoid, and how common VC negotiation tactics can obscure real leverage.

The chapter balances legal wording with practical examples and negotiation strategy. It stresses that valuation alone is not the whole economic story, shows how option pool sizing and warrants effectively alter founder dilution, and contrasts antidilution formulas (full ratchet vs weighted average, broad vs narrow) and their consequences. On the control side it explains typical early‑ and later‑stage board structures, the purpose of protective provisions and conversion triggers, and flags dangerous or overreaching clauses (e.g., adverse‑change redemption, unequal automatic conversion thresholds). The chapter closes by reminding entrepreneurs that term sheets are usually nonbinding and that some seemingly minor “conditions precedent” or binding clauses (no‑shop, legal fees, governing law) deserve close attention.

Valuation is not the whole story (price + other economic terms matter)
Option pool sizing and option budgets

Protective provisions and class voting dynamics
Conversion rights and automatic conversion thresholds
Dividends and redemption rights (including adverse‑change redemption)
Conditions precedent and commonly binding term‑sheet clauses

Control terms that govern decision rights and governance (board makeup, protective provisions, conversion mechanics)
Other deal mechanics and risks to watch (dividends, redemption rights, binding conditions precedent)

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Insist on spelling out key terms prior to a signed term sheet if it has a no-shop
clause in it. A VC who won't spell out key employment terms at the beginning
is a big red flag.

There are plenty of other wacky conditions-if you can dream it
up, it has probably been done. Just make sure to look carefully at this
paragraph and remember that you don't necessarily have a deal just
because you've signed a term sheet.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 6 brings the book’s practical focus down to an entrepreneur’s survival instincts when signing term sheets. Building on the earlier framing of term sheets as the decisive map of economics and control (Chapter 4) and the walk-through of specific provisions that set those axes (Chapter 5), this chapter issues a clear behavioral rule: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop clause, insist that all material deal terms—especially employment and founder‑related terms—be spelled out before you lock yourself into exclusivity. The author warns that some VCs resist committing to employment or other key operational terms early, and that such resistance is a strong red flag. It also reminds readers that term sheets often contain unusual or idiosyncratic conditions—if you can imagine it, it has probably been attempted—so careful scrutiny of the entire document matters.

The core takeaway is procedural and tactical: never let a no‑shop clause be used to limit your options before you have clear, written agreement on the fundamentals of the deal. Signing a term sheet is not the same as having a closed deal; some provisions may be binding while others are conditional, and side letters or follow‑on negotiations can radically change the outcome. This chapter therefore advances the reader’s negotiating playbook from understanding what provisions mean to actively managing timing and information—protecting leverage, demanding early clarity on employment and post‑signing obligations, and watching for hidden or wacky conditions that could undermine the apparent deal.
main_topics: insisting on spelled-out terms before exclusivity
spotting investor red flags
differences between signing and closing
reading and questioning unusual clauses

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first
century. If you can't commit to sending your shareholders a budget and financial
statements, you shouldn't take on outside investors. If you are of the paranoid
mindset (which I generally applaud), feel free to insist on a strict confidentiality
clause to accompany your information rights.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 reframes the negotiations and clause-level detail of the prior chapters from the entrepreneur’s point of view, arguing that information rights are not a villain but a basic requirement of taking on outside capital. Building on the book’s earlier framing of term sheets as the map of economics and control (Chapter 4) and the walk-through of provisions that set those axes (Chapter 5), the chapter counsels founders to run a transparent organization and to be prepared to deliver a budget and regular financial statements. If an entrepreneur is unwilling or unable to commit to those basic disclosures, the chapter bluntly advises against bringing in outside investors.

At the same time, the chapter recognizes the founder’s instinct toward caution: where appropriate, require a confidentiality covenant to accompany investor information rights so sensitive details are protected. The practical upshot is that information rights should be negotiated thoughtfully as part of the control axis—structured to give investors comfort and oversight without surrendering unnecessary operational burden or strategic exposure. For entrepreneurs, embracing reasonable transparency becomes both a practical survival strategy and a selection tool for aligning with investors who respect the company’s rhythm and need for operational independence.
key_concepts: Transparency as a prerequisite for outside investment
main_topics: Why investors demand information rights
What founders should commit to sharing (budgets, financials)
Balancing transparency with confidentiality
Information rights as part of control negotiations

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Don't focus much energy on registration rights. This is more about upside. The
world is good if you're going public.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 recasts the technical negotiation language and clause checklists of earlier chapters into an entrepreneur’s forward‑looking lens. Building on the two axes from Chapter 4 (economics and control) and the clause‑by‑clause anatomy from Chapter 5, and informed by the survival instincts and tradeoffs discussed in Chapter 6 and the reframing of information rights in Chapter 7, this chapter urges founders to prioritize upside in scenarios where an IPO is a realistic outcome. Rather than getting hung up on registration rights or procedural investor protections that matter more in distressed exits, entrepreneurs should focus on structuring economics and governance to maximize participation in a public outcome: preserve meaningful upside per share, limit overly punitive liquidation preferences and destructive anti‑dilution mechanics, protect pro‑rata and option pool economics, and accept reasonable information and governance provisions that prepare the company for public markets.

The chapter also provides a practical mindset shift: treat the term sheet as a tool to align incentives toward a public exit, not only as a defensive battleground over every clause. It emphasizes tactical priorities — what to fight for and what to concede — so that control concessions that materially improve the company’s ability to go public can be acceptable, while hard limits should be kept on provisions that permanently erode founder upside. Registration rights are acknowledged but demoted in importance in a ‘world where you’re going public’; preparing governance, reporting, and capitalization to scale into public markets becomes the entrepreneur’s primary objective.
key_concepts: Information and governance readiness for public markets
main_topics: Prioritizing term‑sheet items that maximize IPO upside
Which investor protections founders should concede vs. resist
Preparing company governance and reporting for public markets

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

The right of first refusal is not a big deal, and in some cases it's good for you.
But make sure you define what a major investor is and give this only to them. At
a minimum, you can make sure that shareholders get this right only if they play
in subsequent rounds.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 9 zooms in on the entrepreneur’s practical stance toward the restriction on sales — the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock — and explains why this provision is typically acceptable and often beneficial for founders and management. Building on the book’s prior mapping of economics and control (Chapter 4) and the clause‑by‑clause anatomy (Chapter 5), the chapter shows that a ROFR helps the company control its shareholder base, maintain alignment among stakeholders, and monitor private transfers in an era of extended liquidity timelines and active second‑ary markets. It also offers a drafting preference: put the ROFR in the bylaws (one central place) rather than scatter it across option agreements and plans, and include language that lets the company assign its ROFR to investors if the company declines to exercise it.

The chapter situates the ROFR in today’s environment — where IPOs are less common, secondaries are common, and the SEC is paying closer attention to private share transfers — and recommends entrepreneurs protect themselves by narrowly defining who receives a transferable ROFR. In practice that means limiting these rights to “major investors” (and carefully defining that term) or conditioning transfer rights on continued participation in later financing rounds. The practical takeaway: ROFRs are not a villainous investor power grab but a reasonable corporate governance tool that founders should accept — with sensible limits and clear drafting to preserve future flexibility and control.
key_concepts: Restriction on Sales / ROFR on common
Placement in corporate documents (bylaws vs option agreements/plans)
Assignment of company’s ROFR to investors
Conditioning rights on participation in subsequent rounds
Impact of secondary markets and extended liquidity
SEC scrutiny of private stock transfers
main_topics: Why ROFR on common benefits the company and founders
Drafting choices and where to put the clause
Historical shift due to longer liquidity timelines and secondary markets
Practical limits: defining major investors and conditional rights

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

A proprietary information and inventions agreement clause is good for the com-
pany. You should have all employees, including founders, sign something like

a specific carve-out for work in progress that is unrelated to the business, you
and your investors should be willing to grant it.
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 10 takes the entrepreneur’s vantage and translates clause-level detail into practical, pre-financing actions and modest negotiation goals. It stresses that a proprietary information and inventions agreement (PIIA) is a necessary and company-friendly document that should be signed by all employees and founders before taking outside capital, while recognizing reasonable carve-outs for unrelated outside work. On the sale-restriction side, the chapter accepts that a co-sale agreement clause is often non-negotiable in practice but urges entrepreneurs to seek a practical floor — for example, allowance for small personal sales (to buy a house) — and to push back if investor mechanisms create an effective exclusion of founder liquidity.
key_concepts: Right of First Refusal (ROFR) with bona fide outside offer
Effective exclusion (de facto blocking of sales)
main_topics: Requiring PIIAs from founders and employees
Negotiating practical limits to co-sale restrictions
Using bona fide outside offers to set ROFR prices
Balancing investor protections with founder liquidity needs

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you can't agree to a founders' activities clause, don't look for professional
VC financing. Or you can negotiate a very specific carve-out, and expect other
consequences in your terms (e.g., vesting and IP rights).
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 11 continues the book’s shift from clause anatomy to the entrepreneur’s pragmatic stance (building on the entrepreneur lens introduced in Chapter 8 and the clause details in Chapter 5). It treats several boilerplate but important term-sheet provisions — primarily the no-shop agreement, indemnification, and assignment — as practical realities entrepreneurs should understand and accommodate rather than fight over needlessly. The chapter stresses that a no-shop is primarily a time-bound, mutual signal to move from “search” to “close”: typically 30–60 days, and useful for testing whether the lead VC is serious about closing. Practical examples show that character and communication often matter more than litigating the clause; exceptions and suspensions sometimes occur when better outcomes (e.g., an acquisition) present themselves. The chapter therefore recommends bounding no-shops with a clear time limit and using them as a way to measure a VC’s commitment rather than as an absolute straitjacket.

Obligations to indemnify directors and investors
VC transfer flexibility and protections for the company
When to accept standard clauses vs. negotiate carve-outs
Reputational and relational dynamics in closing

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. If you do this math, you'll
Example Capitalization Table
Class Shares Preferred Price Valuation Percentage
Founders 2,000,000 A
Employee pool B 20%
Venture investors C D $5,000,000 33.33%
Total E D $15,000,000 100%
see that (2 million + 857,081) * $3.50 = $9,999,783.50. Oops, we are off by $216.50, which represents 62 shares (well, 61.857 shares). While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. Although some get it right, it's your responsibility as the entrepreneur to make sure you understand your cap table. This will be especially helpful at times when you want to expand the employee option pool and you are eloquent in front of your board of directors explaining the ramifications.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 12 turns from clause detail and negotiation stance to the concrete arithmetic every founder must master: the capitalization table (cap table). Building on the fact that a term sheet normally includes a summary cap table, the chapter walks through a typical example (2 million founder shares, $10M pre-money, $5M investment) and shows how to calculate post-money ownership percentages, the number of shares for a promised employee option pool, the shares issued to investors, and the resulting price per share. The worked example highlights that a 20% post-money option pool reduces founder ownership significantly (from 100% to 46.67% in the example), that post-money math determines how many new preferred shares are issued to the VC, and that small rounding issues require fractional-share precision in real cap tables.

The chapter emphasizes practical takeaways: the summary cap table in the term sheet is a starting point but entrepreneurs (not just their lawyers) must understand and be able to generate precise cap tables to evaluate deals, argue about option-pool sizing, and explain dilution to boards and employees. It stresses solving the algebra for unknowns (total shares outstanding, pool shares, VC shares, price per share), checking the arithmetic against the stated pre- and post-money values, and insisting on sufficient numeric precision so that rounding errors do not create discrepancies that matter in negotiation or legal documents.
main_topics: How a summary cap table translates term-sheet economics into shares and percentages
Effect of a post-money option pool on founder ownership
Algebraic steps to solve for total shares, pool shares, investor shares, and price per share
Importance of numeric precision and entrepreneur ownership of the cap table

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 13 shifts from priced equity rounds to a common seed-stage alternative: convertible debt (notes). Building on the term-sheet mechanics previously unpacked, the chapter explains that a convertible note is a loan that usually converts into the next preferred equity round at a discounted effective price. The mechanics are illustrated with numeric examples (e.g., a $500k convertible pool converting at a 20% discount into a $1M Series A at $1/share), and the chapter surfaces the principal economic levers investors and founders negotiate: discount, valuation cap, interest, maturity, and conversion triggers. It stresses practical entrepreneur-facing points — set a reasonable time horizon to force conversion, consider a floor (not a ceiling) on conversion valuation, and be cautious about leaving debt outstanding given debt holders’ stronger enforcement rights compared with equity holders.

The chapter then drills into conversion mechanics (what a “qualified financing” means, minimum raise thresholds, and automatic conversion clauses), governance risks (amendment thresholds and how minority noteholders can create holdout power), and the other ways to give early investors upside: warrants versus discounts. Warrants add complexity (term length, merger treatment, accounting/OID issues) and legal cost; entrepreneurs should avoid double-dipping (discount plus warrants). It contrasts early-stage (seed/bridge) uses with later-stage bridge loans, and presents SAFEs/KISS instruments as alternatives that remove debt dynamics (no maturity, no interest) but trade off some investor protections (e.g., explicit pro-rata or the leverage a maturity date gives). Throughout, the chapter emphasizes how caps and conversion terms affect the cap table and future rounds (linking back to cap table arithmetic and term-sheet negotiation strategy).

conversion mechanics and triggers
governance and amendment risks of outstanding debt
warrants: structure, exercise, and accounting consequences
SAFEs/KISS as non-debt alternatives and trade-offs

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Legal Things Every Entrepreneur Should Know

T.
here are a few legal issues that we've seen consistently become
hurdles for entrepreneurs and their lawyers. While in some cases
they will simply be a hassle to clean up in a financing or an exit,
they often have meaningful financial implications for the company
and, in the worst case, can seriously damage the value of your busi-
ness. We aren't your lawyers or giving you legal advice here (our
lawyers made us write that), but we encourage you to understand
these issues rather than just assume that your lawyer got them right.

If you want to read the best book ever written on legal issues that
face entrepreneurs, get the book The Entrepreneur's Guide to Business
Law, Fourth Edition, by Constance Bagley and Craig Dauchy (South-
Western, 2012). It is written for entrepreneurs, not lawyers, so it's easily
digestible and is the best legal resource we know for entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 14 flags a small set of legal issues that repeatedly create hassles or real value-destroying problems for startups, and it stresses that entrepreneurs should understand them rather than assume lawyers will catch everything. It opens with employment law as the most common source of litigation: make hires "at-will" in offer letters, weigh the pros and cons of prebaking severance, and keep a trusted employment lawyer on call because state laws and discrimination rules vary and can create unpredictable exposures. The chapter then turns to entity choice—C Corp, S Corp, or LLC—explaining why a C Corp is normally required for VC-backed companies (multiple share classes, preferred stock mechanics, deferral of double taxation) while S Corps or LLCs can make sense for small, non-VC businesses because of pass-through tax advantages and simpler ownership structures. Finally, the chapter emphasizes the critical 83(b) election: file within 30 days of receiving restricted stock to preserve capital-gains tax treatment, noting this is an irreversible timing-dependent decision that founders often forget to make and later regret.

Corporate structures: C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC

Irreversible legal missteps and their financial impact

Choosing a Corporate Structure for Funding and Tax

chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 15 shifts the lens from firm-level mechanics (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and recurring legal pitfalls discussed in Chapters 12–14) to the place-based forces that determine where startups cluster and thrive. After summarizing classic explanations from economics, sociology, and geography for why innovation concentrates (including Marshallian external/agglomeration economies and the "spikiness" described by Richard Florida), the chapter proposes a fourth, practice-oriented framework — the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis has four pillars: entrepreneurs must lead the community; leaders must commit for the long term (a working horizon of ~20 years); the community must be inclusive; and it must run continual, hands-on activities that engage the entire "entrepreneurial stack."
main_topics: Why startups cluster geographically
Four components of the Boulder Thesis
Importance of long-term civic entrepreneurship
Practical community activities that create engagement
Resilience across economic cycles
